project_name: CFE Desarrollo Mixto (Esquemas para el Desarrollo Mixto)
description: 7,500 MW across 7 regions by 2030. Mixed public-private model (54% CFE / 46% private). Part of 5.6T MXN investment plan (54% energy). Wind, solar PV, thermal solar + clean sources.
sources: Secretaría de Energía (SENER) and Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE). 2026. Joint announcement on energy projects, February 6–7. Mexico City: SENER; Diario Oficial de la Federación (DOF). 2026. Mexico City: Secretaría de Gobernación; Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039. Mexico City: SENER.

description: 66 priority projects for grid stability in high-tech demand regions. Q4 2025 - end 2026.
sources: Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE). 2025. Institutional project data. Mexico City: CFE; Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.10–4.11. Mexico City: SENER.

description: 158 grid projects, 97 new substations, 95 substation upgrades, 15,729 MVA capacity. Announced April 9, 2025.
sources: Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE). 2025. Institutional project data. Mexico City: CFE; Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.10–4.11. Mexico City: SENER.

description: Almost 25,000 km new transmission lines over 15 years.
sources: Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE). 2025. Institutional project data. Mexico City: CFE; Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.10–4.11. Mexico City: SENER.

description: 6,341.7 km-c transmission lines, 19,759.1 MVA transformation capacity, 12,103.4 MVAr compensation. PLADESE Table 4.10.
sources: Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE). 2025. Institutional project data. Mexico City: CFE; Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.10–4.11. Mexico City: SENER.

description: 2 wind + 4 PV plants. Partnership with Tokyo Gas. Financed in part by USD 60M from Proparco.
sources: ENGIE, S.A. Various years. Corporate project documentation and press releases. Paris: ENGIE; Tokyo Gas Co., Ltd. Various years. Partnership documentation. Tokyo: Tokyo Gas; Proparco (Groupe Agence Française de Développement). Various years. Development finance project records. Paris: Proparco.

description: 5,551 MW battery storage 2025-2030 across all 8 GCRs. PLADESE Ch. 3.
sources: Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.1–4.8. Mexico City: SENER, con información del Centro Nacional de Control de Energía (CENACE).

description: 3,096 MW additional battery storage 2031-2039. PLADESE Ch. 3.
sources: Secretaría de Energía (SENER). 2025. Programa para el Desarrollo del Sistema Eléctrico Nacional (PRODESEN) 2025–2039, Chapter 4, Tables 4.1–4.8. Mexico City: SENER, con información del Centro Nacional de Control de Energía (CENACE).

description: Coal-fired thermoelectric plant with 4 units of 350 MW each. Located in Nava, Coahuila. One of Mexico's three major coal plants.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Coal-fired thermoelectric plant in Nava, Coahuila. Four units of 300 MW each. Burns approximately 16,000 tons of coal daily. Part of Carbón II complex.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Mexico's largest coal-fired power plant. Six original 350 MW units commissioned in 1993-1994, plus 678 MW Pacífico expansion unit added in 2010. Located in Petacalco, La Unión de Isidoro Montes de Oca, Guerrero. Burns approximately 7 million tons of coal annually. Generates roughly 7% of Mexico's electricity.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Tuxpan, Veracruz. Part of Tuxpan complex with multiple units.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

project_name: Tuxpan II and V Combined Cycle
description: Combined cycle natural gas power plants in Tuxpan, Veracruz. Units II and V of the Tuxpan complex.
sources: NAES

project_name: Tuxpan III and IV Combined Cycle
description: Combined cycle natural gas power plants in Tuxpan, Veracruz. Units III and IV of the Tuxpan complex. Total capacity at least 1,180 MW.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Salamanca, Guanajuato. Operating combined cycle facility.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

project_name: Salamanca II (Planta de Ciclo Combinado Salamanca II)
description: New combined cycle natural gas power plant. Approved for construction in Salamanca, Guanajuato. Commenced operations in 2024.
sources: proyectosmexico.gob.mx

project_name: Tula (Central CC Tula / Francisco Pérez Ríos)
description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Tula de Allende, Hidalgo. Multiple units with at least 890 MW capacity. Some units not currently operating.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: New combined cycle natural gas power plant in Tula, Hidalgo. Approved for construction as part of 2025-2030 expansion plan. Capacity 912 MW (1,013 MW gross).
sources: Energy and Commerce Mexico, SENER

project_name: Valle de México (Central Termoeléctrica Valle de México)
description: Combined cycle thermoelectric power plant in Ecatepec, Estado de México. Multiple units with at least 1,164 MW capacity. Some units not currently operating.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

project_name: Valle de México II (Central de Ciclo Combinado Valle de México II)
description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant. Net capacity of 615 MW in Estado de México. Part of CFE's generation expansion.
sources: proyectosmexico.gob.mx

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Mérida, Yucatán Peninsula. Merida III has 505 MW capacity. Completed construction and operational.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Valladolid, Quintana Roo. CCC Riviera Maya has 750 MW capacity. Expected to enter service 2023. A 1,020 MW expansion slated for 2027.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant. Net capacity of 888 MW in El Carmen, Nuevo León. Also referenced as Escobedo power station.
sources: proyectosmexico.gob.mx, Global Energy Monitor

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant in Mexicali, Baja California. Net capacity estimated at 600-768 MW. Under construction, anticipated to begin commercial operations in July 2025, with revised estimates placing operation in 2026.
sources: Global Energy Monitor, BNamericas

description: New combined cycle natural gas power plant. Approved for construction in Altamira, Tamaulipas. Part of 2025-2030 CFE expansion plan. Approximate net capacity 581 MW.
sources: Energy and Commerce Mexico, SENER

description: New combined cycle natural gas power plant. Approved for construction in Mazatlán, Sinaloa. Part of 2025-2030 CFE expansion plan. Capacity 575 MW (581 MW reported in some sources).
sources: Energy and Commerce Mexico, SENER

project_name: Los Cabos (Central de Generación Interna de Los Cabos)
description: Internal combustion power plant in Los Cabos, Baja California Sur. 13 high-efficiency internal combustion engines with approximate capacity 240 MW. Can operate on diesel in case of emergency. Part of 2025-2030 expansion plan.
sources: SENER, Energy and Commerce Mexico

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant operated by Grupo Naturgy. Entered commercial operation on August 7, 2010. Operates exclusively on natural gas.
sources: Global Power Generation

description: Combined cycle natural gas power plant. El Sauz II recently inaugurated as part of CFE's generation expansion.
sources: Riviera Maya News

description: New combined cycle natural gas plant in San Luis Río Colorado, Sonora. Capacity 680 MW. Expected completion May 2024.
sources: SENER

description: 269-MW combined cycle power plant in Querétaro. CFE facility to boost Bajío grid.
sources: Mexico News Daily

description: Conventional thermoelectric power plant in Coahuila. Part of CFE's thermal generation fleet.
sources: Global Energy Monitor

description: Three cogeneration plants in partnership with PEMEX. Combined capacity 2,422 MW. Expected to become operational between 2029 and 2030. Estimated investment US$2.059 billion.
sources: SENER PRODESEN 2022-2036

description: Planned combined cycle natural gas plants for 2022-2025 period. Total capacity 5,671 MW of combined cycle capacity plus 1,508 MW of internal combustion planned.
sources: SENER PRODESEN 2022-2036

description: PRODESEN 2024 contemplates converting 5,789 MW of existing combined cycle capacity into clean production 2033-2036 by operating with 75% natural gas and 25% green hydrogen blend. Additional 1,829 MW from new facilities with hydrogen blend. Total CCC capacity 3,481 MW planned for 2026-2036.
sources: SENER PRODESEN 2024-2038

description: Planned internal combustion power plants for 2022-2025 period. Total capacity 1,508 MW. Can operate on diesel fuel for emergency backup.
sources: SENER PRODESEN 2022-2036

description: New solar power plant with battery storage at Carbon II site in Coahuila. Part of CFE renewable expansion. Construction start February 2026.
sources: Strategic Energy Europe. 2025. "Mexico to add over 1.5 GW of clean power and storage." https://strategicenergy.eu/mexico-to-add-over-1-5-gw-of-clean-power-and-storage-as-it-expands-latin-americas-largest-solar-plant/. Accessed February 2026.

description: New solar power plant with battery storage at Rio Escondido site in Coahuila. Part of CFE renewable expansion. Construction start February 2026.
sources: Strategic Energy Europe. 2025. "Mexico to add over 1.5 GW of clean power and storage." https://strategicenergy.eu/mexico-to-add-over-1-5-gw-of-clean-power-and-storage-as-it-expands-latin-americas-largest-solar-plant/. Accessed February 2026.

project_name: Rincon del Arco Solar Complex (Phase I)
description: Large private solar complex in Mina, Nuevo Leon. Phase I of 720 MW total. Deploying 770,000+ solar panels across ~1,000 hectares. Submitted for environmental permitting Dec 2025.
sources: PV Magazine. 2025. "New large-scale PV projects proliferate in Mexico." https://www.pv-magazine.com/2025/11/26/new-large-scale-pv-projects-proliferate-in-mexico/. Accessed February 2026.

project_name: Rincon del Arco Solar Complex (Phase II)
description: Phase II of large private solar complex in Mina, Nuevo Leon. Part of 720 MW total project.
sources: PV Magazine. 2025. "New large-scale PV projects proliferate in Mexico." https://www.pv-magazine.com/2025/11/26/new-large-scale-pv-projects-proliferate-in-mexico/. Accessed February 2026.

description: Solar plant in Durango under mixed development scheme with FONADIN and SENER. Part of portfolio of assets acquired by Mexican state from Iberdrola.
sources: Strategic Energy Europe. 2025. "Mexico to add over 1.5 GW of clean power and storage." https://strategicenergy.eu/mexico-to-add-over-1-5-gw-of-clean-power-and-storage-as-it-expands-latin-americas-largest-solar-plant/. Accessed February 2026.

description: Wind farm in Juchitan, Oaxaca. 100 MW. Submitted for environmental permitting Jan 2026.
sources: PV Magazine. 2025. "New large-scale PV projects proliferate in Mexico." https://www.pv-magazine.com/2025/11/26/new-large-scale-pv-projects-proliferate-in-mexico/. Accessed February 2026.

description: World's largest solar-powered food market. 18 MW rooftop solar installation at Mexico City's Central de Abasto wholesale market, covering 130,000 m2.
sources: Revolve Renewable Power. 2024. "Mexico City's New Solar Power Plant Is Largest of Its Kind in the World." Revolve Renewable Power, accessed February 2026.

description: New 350 MW combined cycle gas turbine unit at CFE's existing Manzanillo thermoelectric complex. Operational August 2025.
sources: Mexico Business News. 2024. "CFE Expands Manzanillo Plant With New 350MW Power Unit." Mexico Business News, accessed February 2026.

description: Utility-scale 130 MW solar PV park in western Tlaxcala. Currently in permitting stage.
sources: Power Technology. 2024. "Tlaxcala West Solar PV Park, Mexico." Power Technology, accessed February 2026.
